title: Move review reporter rendering to CLI layer

task.title: Move review reporter rendering to CLI layer
task.description:
`core/review/reporter.py` is the heaviest Rich violator — it's ~90% Rich rendering. The data models already exist in `core/review/models.py`. We need to split data preparation from rendering.

**Implementation Steps:**
1. Audit `core/review/reporter.py` to identify data preparation vs rendering
2. Keep any data transformation logic in core; move to `core/review/formatter.py` if needed (returns structured data)
3. Create `cli/review/display.py` with all Rich rendering (Panel, Table, Text)
4. Update `cli/review.py` to call display functions instead of core reporter
5. Remove Rich imports from `core/review/reporter.py` (or delete if fully moved)
6. Update tests to verify data output, not rendered output

**Files:** src/cub/core/review/reporter.py, src/cub/cli/review/display.py, src/cub/cli/review.py

commits.message: task(cub-b1b.1): Move review reporter rendering to CLI layer

outcome.approach: Performed a systematic refactor to separate data preparation from Rich rendering by auditing the monolithic `reporter.py` file, extracting all Rich components into a new CLI layer display class, consolidating core formatting logic, and resolving a Python module/package shadowing conflict by moving CLI commands into a package structure.
decisions: Resolved Python's module/package name collision by consolidating `cli/review.py` into `cli/review/__init__.py` rather than renaming the directory, maintaining the existing `cub review` command interface
Kept `to_json()` logic in core as a standalone formatter function rather than as a method, enabling cleaner separation of concerns and avoiding class dependencies
Moved all Rich rendering (Panel, Table, Text styling) into a dedicated `ReviewDisplay` class in the CLI layer rather than as standalone functions, maintaining a cohesive rendering abstraction
Deleted `core/review/reporter.py` entirely after migration rather than leaving a stub, ensuring no accidental re-imports of the old interface
lessons_learned: Python's module/package resolution prefers directories over files when both exist with the same name—consolidation into `__init__.py` is cleaner than post-hoc renaming
Complete deletion of migrated code (rather than deprecation) forces discovery of all import sites early and prevents technical debt accumulation
Separating data formatting from rendering requires explicit boundaries: keeping formatters in core (no UI imports) and display logic in CLI enables testing and future interface flexibility
Comprehensive test validation across the entire suite (650+ tests) should be run immediately after refactoring to catch shadowing and import issues that linting alone might miss
